Nardelli, the former chief executive of Home Depot, refused to bend to the will of an exasperated board and accept a pay cut, he lost the crucial support of a friend who as lead director not only recruited him but presided over his compensation contract that would later draw so much fire, according to a report in The New York Times. ", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2007/01/05/how-home-depots-nardelli-lost-a-key-ally/", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": " Everyone who knows him says it: In a tough fight, Kenneth G. Langone is a guy you want in your corner. But when Robert L. Nardelli, the former chief executive of Home Depot, refused to bend to the will of an exasperated board and accept a pay cut, he lost the crucial support of a friend who as lead director not only recruited him but presided over his compensation contract that would later draw so much fire, according to a report in The New York Times. Nardelli, the recently dismissed chief executive, will leave the board in 2008. A founder of Relational, David H. Batchelder, will join the Home Depot board on Feb. 22, and the investment fund will drop its proxy challenge, the two companies said in a joint statement. {"abstract": " Home Depot\u2018s chief executive, Frank Blake, offered a reality check Wednesday to those who are hoping his company will soon become the biggest buyout target in history. \u201cWe\u2019re not thinking about going private,\u201d Mr. Blake said at a Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce conference. \u201cWe\u2019re very pleased with the capital structure we have.\u201d There has been speculation that Home Depot\u2019s stalled stock price and its valuable real-estate assets could make the home-improvement retailer an attractive acquisition candidate for private equity firms. {"abstract": "Radiosophy's HD100 pulls in HD Radio signals, a digital format that is broadcast alongside standard radio by more than 1,200 stations in this country.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/31/technology/31radio.html", "snippet": "Radiosophy's HD100 pulls in HD Radio signals, a digital format that is broadcast alongside standard radio by more than 1,200 stations in this country.", "lead_paragraph": "The cost of receiving digital AM and FM signals will drop next week as Radiosophy releases its HD100 receiver for less than $60 with a rebate. {"abstract": "Plextor has come out with its Mini Digital HDTV Receiver, which connects to a laptop\u2019s U.S.B. port.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/07/technology/07hdtv.html", "snippet": "Plextor has come out with its Mini Digital HDTV Receiver, which connects to a laptop\u2019s U.S.B. port.", "lead_paragraph": "It\u2019s summertime, and catching your favorite TV shows is not so easy when you are on vacation or a weekend outing. A cheap, portable TV is one option, but what if you\u2019ve developed a taste for high definition? Plextor has come out with its Mini Digital HDTV Receiver, which connects to a laptop\u2019s U.S.B. port. [{"abstract": "The ongoing troubles in the debt markets may have rocked yet another major buyout. {"abstract": "The death of the paper airline ticket is finally at hand.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/09/18/they-lasted-longer-than-airline-meals-did/", "snippet": "The death of the paper airline ticket is finally at hand.", "lead_paragraph": "It\u2019s a rare and exotic thing these days to see someone at an airport holding a paper ticket, especially the old multi-layered red-inked carbon copy variety that remind us of when PanAm was still in business. People with paper tickets are like the conspicuous outliers at Home Depot who clog the line by trying to pay with cash. ", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "They Lasted Longer Than Airline Meals Did", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2007-09-18T16:45:37+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Katie Hafner", "person": [{"firstname": "Katie", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Hafner", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/461bdb15-8665-503a-939d-08f9f75d270b", "word_count": 262, "uri": "nyt://article/461bdb15-8665-503a-939d-08f9f75d270b"}

{"abstract": "Warner Brothers, the only studio to back both high-definition video disk formats, now will only publish movies in Blu-ray. Some say this shift will quickly kill the competing HD DVD format.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/01/04/did-warner-brothers-just-kill-hd-dvd/", "snippet": "Warner Brothers, the only studio to back both high-definition video disk formats, now will only publish movies in Blu-ray. Some say this shift will quickly kill the competing HD DVD format.", "lead_paragraph": "In addition to Apple, Warner Brothers is now going to throw its weight behind the Blu-ray format for high-definition disks. Warner has been the only major studio to publish its movies in both Blu-ray and HD DVD formats. Today, the studio announced that from now on, it would only issue movies in Blu-ray.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Did Warner Brothers Just Kill HD DVD?", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2008-01-04T22:37:41+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Saul Hansell", "person": [{"firstname": "Saul", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Hansell", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/3141c2d7-0b0f-5238-a2da-5dd758fd9eb4", "word_count": 201, "uri": "nyt://article/3141c2d7-0b0f-5238-a2da-5dd758fd9eb4"}

[{"abstract": "The press conference for Toshiba, creator of the HD DVD format, felt more like a funeral following the news last week that gives the rival Blu-ray format momentum.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/01/06/does-hd-dvd-have-a-future/", "snippet": "The press conference for Toshiba, creator of the HD DVD format, felt more like a funeral following the news last week that gives the rival Blu-ray format momentum.", "lead_paragraph": "It had all the feeling of a wake, not a celebration. {"abstract": "A report says that the last two studios to back Toshiba\u2019s HD DVD format \u2014 NBC Universal and Paramount \u2014 are backing away from their exclusive commitment in the wake of Warner Brothers\u2019 endorsement of the rival Blu-ray format. {"abstract": "Instead of Blu-ray discs, some wonder if movies could be sold on flash memory cards. Flash, it turns out, is still too expensive and too slow to make this cost-effective.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/02/22/buying-movies-on-flash-cards-nice-idea-that-doesnt-work/", "snippet": "Instead of Blu-ray discs, some wonder if movies could be sold on flash memory cards. Flash, it turns out, is still too expensive and too slow to make this cost-effective.", "lead_paragraph": "Over the last few months, we\u2019ve had quite a debate in the comments here about the relative merits of Blu-ray, HD DVD and standard DVD discs. Some argue we don\u2019t need discs at all because we\u2019ll all be able to download movies. And others have suggested that the price of memory chips is falling so fast that we might still buy movies in stores, but they may come loaded on U.S.B. memory sticks or the sort of SD memory cards that go in digital cameras. {"abstract": "Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, may cut as many as 1,000 jobs as it reduces human-resources departments in stores by half to shift more workers to the sales floor.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/05/business/05biztoday-003.html", "snippet": "Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, may cut as many as 1,000 jobs as it reduces human-resources departments in stores by half to shift more workers to the sales floor.", "lead_paragraph": "HOME DEPOT JOB CUTS Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, may cut as many as 1,000 jobs as it reduces human-resources departments in stores by half to shift more workers to the sales floor. About 2,200 workers were notified of possible changes, and affected full-time employees, less than 1 percent of its work force, can apply for other jobs at the Atlanta-based company, a spokesman said Friday. The job cuts are effective May 1. {"abstract": "For NBC\u2019s coverage of 13 Olympic sports, the announcers are not in Beijing, but in New York.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/08/14/olympics-in-the-announcers-booth-but-not-in-beijing/", "snippet": "For NBC\u2019s coverage of 13 Olympic sports, the announcers are not in Beijing, but in New York.", "lead_paragraph": "For NBC\u2019s coverage of 13 Olympic sports, the announcers are not in Beijing, but in New York: at 30 Rockefeller Plaza actually, on the temporarily vacated set of \u201cSaturday Night Live,\u201d inside 14-foot-wide booths \u201cthat are equipped with 24-inch HD monitors and headsets that pipe in the ambient sounds from the game sites,\u201d Richard Sandomir reports.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Olympics: In the Announcers\u2019 Booth, but Not in Beijing", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2008-08-14T15:15:16+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Media", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By The New York Times", "person": [], "organization": "The New York Times"}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/eaa92f92-c655-5f56-8947-892035a70c47", "word_count": 87, "uri": "nyt://article/eaa92f92-c655-5f56-8947-892035a70c47"}

{"abstract": "Saks said it lost more than expected in the third quarter amid job losses on Wall Street and stock market turmoil, while Home Depot said quarterly profit sank 31 percent on slow sales.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/19/business/19shop.html", "snippet": "Saks said it lost more than expected in the third quarter amid job losses on Wall Street and stock market turmoil, while Home Depot said quarterly profit sank 31 percent on slow sales.", "lead_paragraph": "Of all the categories in American retailing, high-end clothing and home improvement could not be more different. {"abstract": "The Tough-3000 is the first of the company\u2019s rugged line to offer HD video capture (720p) and is also the most affordable Tough model at $230.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/14/technology/personaltech/14olympus.html", "snippet": "The Tough-3000 is the first of the company\u2019s rugged line to offer HD video capture (720p) and is also the most affordable Tough model at $230.", "lead_paragraph": "Olympus unwrapped its Stylus Tough-3000 camera at the Consumer Electronics Show last week. The Tough-3000 is the first of the company\u2019s rugged line to offer HD video capture (720p) and is also the most affordable Tough model at $230. The Stylus Tough-3000 can withstand a five-foot drop, is submersible to 10 feet and works in temperatures as low as 14 degrees. {"abstract": "In making share buybacks, companies have a long record of buying high and selling low.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/30/business/30views.html", "snippet": "In making share buybacks, companies have a long record of buying high and selling low.", "lead_paragraph": "Home Depot investors cheered the company\u2019s new stock repurchase plan, adding about $1.5 billion to its market value on Tuesday. History suggests they should curb some of their enthusiasm. American companies have a terrible track record of buying their own shares high and selling them low. Home Depot\u2019s $1 billion program adds to the $136 billion of buybacks announced this year. Only the market peak of 2007 had more such activity. That\u2019s not a good sign.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "A Bad Record on Buybacks", "kicker": "Reuters Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "A Bad Record on Buybacks", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Stocks and Bonds", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Executives and Management", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Glencore International AG", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-03-30T01:31:19+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By ROBERT CYRAN and CHRISTOPHER HUGHES", "person": [{"firstname": "Robert", "middlename": null, "lastname": "CYRAN", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}, {"firstname": "Christopher", "middlename": null, "lastname": "HUGHES", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 2}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/16ad1184-cc49-5532-8d41-ee0dd09ad2ab", "word_count": 711, "uri": "nyt://article/16ad1184-cc49-5532-8d41-ee0dd09ad2ab"}

{"abstract": "Data will include retail sales and leading economic indicators for July, and companies reporting results will include Groupon, Home Depot and Wal-Mart Stores.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/13/business/economic-reports-for-the-week-of-aug-13.html", "snippet": "Data will include retail sales and leading economic indicators for July, and companies reporting results will include Groupon, Home Depot and Wal-Mart Stores.", "lead_paragraph": "ECONOMIC REPORTS The data will include retail sales for July, the producer price index for July and business inventories for June (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for July and industrial production for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for July, and the Philadelphia Fed index for August\u00a0(Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for August and leading economic indicators for July (Friday).", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Economic Reports for the Week Ahead", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Looking Ahead", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Economic Conditions and Trends", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-08-12T21:38:09+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Schedule", "_id": "nyt://article/c9679563-4622-55cd-9251-b2b32f9a059b", "word_count": 265, "uri": "nyt://article/c9679563-4622-55cd-9251-b2b32f9a059b"}

{"abstract": "The location of the nation\u2019s top colleges reflects the past as much as the present. As a result, many students who live far away from such colleges \u2013 especially in the Sun Belt and Mountain West \u2013 suffer.", "web_url": "https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/08/how-the-location-of-colleges-hurts-the-economy/", "snippet": "The location of the nation\u2019s top colleges reflects the past as much as the present. As a result, many students who live far away from such colleges \u2013 especially in the Sun Belt and Mountain West \u2013 suffer.", "lead_paragraph": "Some of the nation\u2019s most important companies did not exist a generation ago, and many of the most important \u2013 Amazon.com, Google, Apple, Costco, Home Depot, Microsoft, FedEx \u2013 did not exist 50 years ago. The federal government has also been transformed over the last century, with the creation of Social Security, Medicare, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the modern Federal Reserve and dozens of other agencies and programs.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "How the Location of Colleges Hurts the Economy", "kicker": "Economix", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Colleges and Universities", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "States (US)", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-04-08T15:00:04+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Economy", "byline": {"original": "By David Leonhardt", "person": [{"firstname": "David", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Leonhardt", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/e14d31d1-1b4a-50a7-a890-bf8c87b6a1ec", "word_count": 796, "uri": "nyt://article/e14d31d1-1b4a-50a7-a890-bf8c87b6a1ec"}

HD Supply, a former Home Depot division that serves construction and maintenance contractors, priced its stock sale at $18 a share on Wednesday, well below its expected range. Tremor Video, a leading video advertising network, priced its offering at $10 a share, below an anticipated range of $11 to $13, according to a person briefed on the matter. Steinberg, the most senior employee at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors indicted in insider trading. Federal prosecutors have accused Mr. Steinberg of trading on secret information about technology companies. Though SAC has been at the center of the government\u2019s insider trading investigation for years, Mr. Steinberg is the first former SAC employee to stand trial. Six others, including the fund itself, have pleaded guilty. {"abstract": "Over the past 15 years, something palpable has begun to change at big companies, Tony Schwartz writes. {"abstract": "General Motors is recalling almost 118,000 of its 2013-14 model vehicles including the Chevrolet Tahoe and Cadillac Escalade.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/03/business/gm-recalls-more-cars-over-possible-stalling.html", "snippet": "General Motors is recalling almost 118,000 of its 2013-14 model vehicles including the Chevrolet Tahoe and Cadillac Escalade.", "lead_paragraph": "General Motors is recalling almost 118,000 of its 2013-14 model vehicles because they may stall or fail to start, the company said on Thursday. The action includes almost 98,000 vehicles in the United States, Alan Adler, a G.M. spokesman, wrote in an email. The remaining vehicles are in Canada, Mexico and some export markets. Slivers of metal in the chassis control module could cause an electrical short, Mr. Adler said. He said the automaker was not aware of any accidents or injuries related to the defect. The affected models are the 2013-14 Chevrolet Tahoe and Suburban; 2013-14 Cadillac CTS; 2013-14 GMC Yukon and Yukon XL; 2013-14 Cadillac Escalade and Escalade ESV; 2014 Chevrolet Traverse; 2014 GMC Acadia; 2014 Buick Enclave; 2014 Chevrolet Express and GMC Savana and the 2014 Chevrolet Silverado HD and GMC Sierra HD. This is the automaker\u2019s 69th recall this year and brings the number of vehicles recalled in the United States to just over 26 million. {"abstract": "Companies still need to invest in cyberprotection and detection, says Richard Beales of Reuters Breakingviews.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/12/23/the-need-for-bank-cyberinsurance/", "snippet": "Companies still need to invest in cyberprotection and detection, says Richard Beales of Reuters Breakingviews.", "lead_paragraph": "A high-profile hack at JPMorgan \u00a0Chase \u2013 to say nothing of monstrous breaches at Sony and Home Depot \u2013 has made cybersecurity a daily concern for executives at big banks and corporations. {"abstract": "Walmart, Home Depot and Target are among the retailers posting results this week; Japan will report its G.D.P. on Wednesday; and the big Wall Street banks will hold their annual meetings with shareholders.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/18/business/earnings-from-walmart-and-more-big-retailers-wall-streets-annual-meetings.html", "snippet": "Walmart, Home Depot and Target are among the retailers posting results this week; Japan will report its G.D.P. on Wednesday; and the big Wall Street banks will hold their annual meetings with shareholders.", "lead_paragraph": "A wave of retailers will report first-quarter earnings this week, including Home Depot, Walmart and TJX on Tuesday; Target, Lowe\u2019s and Staples on Wednesday; and Best Buy, Gap, Ross Stores and Dollar Tree on Thursday. Analysts are paying particular attention to how well these stores weathered the post-holiday lull and wintry weather early this year. They will also be looking for effects of rising labor costs as a tightening job market forces retailers \u2014 some of the country\u2019s largest employers \u2014 to start increasing wages for their lowest-paid workers. \u2014Hiroko Tabuchi", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-articleLarge.jpg", "height": 407, "width": 600, "subType": "xlarge", "crop_name": "articleLarge", "legacy": {"xlarge": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-articleLarge.jpg", "xlargewidth": 600, "xlargeheight": 407}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-jumbo.jpg", "height": 694, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "superJumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-superJumbo.jpg", "height": 1388, "width": 2048, "subType": "superJumbo", "crop_name": "superJumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-thumbStandard.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-thumbStandard.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbLarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-thumbLarge.jpg", "height": 150, "width": 150, "subType": "thumbLarge", "crop_name": "thumbLarge", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Earnings From Walmart and More Big Retailers; {"abstract": "This week, some of the nation's biggest retailers report earnings, the Federal Reserve will publish an account of its July meeting, and Greece must make a critical repayment.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/17/business/retailer-earnings-fed-minutes-and-greek-debt.html", "snippet": "This week, some of the nation's biggest retailers report earnings, the Federal Reserve will publish an account of its July meeting, and Greece must make a critical repayment.", "lead_paragraph": "Some of the nation\u2019s biggest retailers report earnings this week, including Walmart and Home Depot, which announce second-quarter results on Tuesday, and Target, whose announcement is on Wednesday. Walmart has invested heavily in its stores, as well as in its online business and work force, as part of a bid to overcome a prolonged decline in sales and market share. Still, analysts do not expect big results soon. On the other hand, Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, has been riding a recovery in the housing market to sales gains, and analysts expect it to book a solid quarter. Also reporting this week are TJX on Tuesday; Staples, Lowe\u2019s and American Eagle Outfitters on Wednesday; and Foot Locker on Friday. \u2014Hiroko Tabuchi", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2",
